history.additional_context:
--- CONTEXT ENTRY BEGIN ---
This section (like others) contains important information that I want you to use in your responses. I have gathered this context from valuable programmatic script hooks. You must follow any requests and consider all of the information in this section

'git-status': 

--- CONTEXT ENTRY END ---

Prompt.prompt:
this repo contains a simple app which I created with a single prompt:

REQUIREMENTS:

Input:

Accept conversation source URL (file/gist) via query parameter
Support multiple source types through adapter pattern
Support multiple conversation formats through parser adapters
Core Features:

Parse and identify:
Human messages
Agent responses
Tool calls/system messages (including failures)
Interactive playback:
Typewriter text animation
Enter key to progress
Tab key to complete current message
Ghost preview of upcoming user messages
Configurable animation speeds
Progress indicators
UI/UX:

Terminal-style interface with:
Monospace font
Cursor animations
Command prompt styling
Message type indicators
Settings panel:
Animation speed controls (separate for human/agent)
Terminal theme options
Visual preferences
System-aware dark mode
Minimal, developer-focused aesthetic
Clear interaction instructions
Technical Implementation:

Vue 3 Composition API
Vite build system
CSS Architecture:
Global stylesheet for common elements
Scoped component styles
CSS custom properties for theming
Component Structure:
Source adapters (FileAdapter, GistAdapter)
Parser adapters (format-specific)
Terminal component
Settings panel
Message renderer
Animation controller
Clean Architecture:
Separate concerns (parsing, rendering, playback)
State management
Event handling
Configuration management
Deliverables:

Modular, maintainable codebase
Responsive, accessible interface
Extensible adapter system
Documentation for adding new sources/formats
Attached, you find two sample formats:

a text format, copied from the shell. User messages are identifyable with the > and may be multi-line. Consider all lines that follow until there's an empty line as one prompt.
a json format, exported from q-developer. There, all user prompts can be identified by content.Prompt
---

the LLM responded with 

---
Based on your requirements, I'll create a comprehensive Vue.js application for replaying LLM conversations with a terminal-style interface and interactive playback features. We'll focus on a clean, developer-focused aesthetic with extensible adapter architecture.

Core Features:

Source and parser adapter pattern for multiple conversation formats
Interactive playback with typewriter animations and keyboard controls
Terminal-style interface with cursor animations and command prompt styling
Settings panel for animation speeds and visual preferences
Real-time progress indicators and ghost preview system
Design Elements:

Monospace typography with terminal aesthetics and proper contrast ratios
System-aware dark mode with comprehensive color system (6+ color ramps)
Responsive design with mobile (<768px), tablet (768-1024px), and desktop (>1024px) breakpoints
8px spacing system with intentional white space and visual hierarchy
Subtle animations and micro-interactions for enhanced user engagement
LLM Conversation Replay Vue.js Application

Revert

package.json
npm install
src/App.vue
src/components/SourceInput.vue
src/components/SettingsPanel.vue
src/components/ConversationTerminal.vue
src/components/MessageRenderer.vue
src/components/TypewriterText.vue
src/components/ProgressIndicator.vue
src/types/index.ts
src/adapters/FileSourceAdapter.ts
src/adapters/GistSourceAdapter.ts
src/parsers/TextFormatParser.ts
src/parsers/JsonFormatParser.ts
src/style.css
npm run dev
I've created a comprehensive Vue.js application for replaying LLM conversations with all the features you requested. The application includes:

Architecture & Features Implemented:

Source Adapters: FileSourceAdapter and GistSourceAdapter for different content sources
Parser Adapters: TextFormatParser for shell-style format and JsonFormatParser for Q-Developer format
Interactive Playback: Typewriter animations, Enter/Tab/Esc controls, and auto-play functionality
Terminal Interface: Monospace fonts, cursor animations, command prompt styling with message type indicators
Settings Panel: Animation speed controls, theme selection, and visual preference toggles
Design & UX:

System-aware dark mode with 4 terminal themes (Matrix, Amber, Blue, Hacker)
Responsive design with proper breakpoints for mobile, tablet, and desktop
8px spacing system with consistent typography and visual hierarchy
Micro-interactions including hover states, transitions, and progress indicators
Accessible contrast ratios and readable typography throughout
Technical Implementation:

Vue 3 Composition API with TypeScript for type safety
Clean component architecture with separation of concerns
Extensible adapter pattern for easy addition of new sources and formats
Local storage for user preferences and settings persistence
URL parameter support for direct source loading
The application can parse both your sample formats - the shell-style text format (with > for user messages) and the Q-Developer JSON format. The demo button provides an immediate example of how conversations replay with typewriter effects.

To extend the application with new formats or sources, simply create new adapter classes implementing the respective interfaces. The modular design makes it easy to add features like audio playback, export functionality, or additional conversation sources.
---

Create a comprehensive readme that your colleague missd out on

args.new_str:
# LLM Conversation Replay Player

A Vue.js application for replaying LLM conversations with an interactive terminal-style interface. Features typewriter animations, keyboard controls, and support for multiple conversation formats through an extensible adapter system.

![Demo](https://img.shields.io/badge/demo-live-brightgreen) ![Vue 3](https://img.shields.io/badge/Vue-3-4FC08D) ![TypeScript](https://img.shields.io/badge/TypeScript-007ACC) ![Vite](https://img.shields.io/badge/Vite-646CFF)

## ‚ú® Features

### üé¨ Interactive Playback
- **Typewriter animations** with configurable speeds for human and agent messages
- **Keyboard controls**: Enter to progress, Tab to complete current message, Esc to pause
- **Auto-play mode** with customizable timing
- **Ghost preview** of upcoming user messages
- **Progress indicators** showing conversation completion

### üñ•Ô∏è Terminal Interface
- **Authentic terminal styling** with monospace fonts and cursor animations
- **Command prompt aesthetics** with message type indicators
- **Multiple themes**: Matrix, Amber, Blue, Hacker, and Light modes
- **Window styles**: macOS, Linux, and Windows terminal appearances
- **System-aware dark mode** with proper contrast ratios

### üîå Extensible Architecture
- **Source adapters** for different content sources (File, Gist, URL)
- **Parser adapters** for multiple conversation formats
- **Modular component system** with clean separation of concerns
- **TypeScript interfaces** for easy extension

### ‚öôÔ∏è Customization
- **Animation speed controls** (separate for human/agent messages)
- **Visual preferences** (themes, window styles, progress indicators)
- **Settings persistence** via localStorage
- **Responsive design** for mobile, tablet, and desktop

## üöÄ Quick Start

### Prerequisites
- Node.js 16+ 
- npm or yarn

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone <repository-url>
cd rpl

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start development server
npm run dev
```

### Usage

1. **Load a conversation**:
   - Enter a file URL or GitHub Gist URL in the source input
   - Or use the demo button to see a sample conversation
   - Supported URL formats:
     - `file://path/to/conversation.txt`
     - `https://gist.github.com/username/gist-id`

2. **Control playback**:
   - **Enter**: Advance to next message
   - **Tab**: Complete current typewriter animation
   - **Esc**: Pause/resume auto-play
   - **Settings icon**: Open customization panel

3. **Customize experience**:
   - Adjust animation speeds for different message types
   - Choose from 5 terminal themes
   - Toggle progress indicators and ghost previews
   - Select window style (macOS/Linux/Windows)

## üìÅ Project Structure

```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/           # Vue components
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationTerminal.vue    # Main terminal interface
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ MessageRenderer.vue         # Individual message display
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ TypewriterText.vue         # Typewriter animation
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SourceInput.vue            # URL input and loading
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SettingsPanel.vue          # Configuration panel
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ProgressIndicator.vue      # Progress tracking
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ adapters/            # Source adapters
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ FileSourceAdapter.ts       # Local file loading
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ GistSourceAdapter.ts       # GitHub Gist integration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ parsers/             # Format parsers
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ TextFormatParser.ts        # Shell-style text format
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ JsonFormatParser.ts        # Q-Developer JSON format
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types/               # TypeScript definitions
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts                   # Core interfaces
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ App.vue              # Root component
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.ts              # Application entry point
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ style.css            # Global styles and themes
```

## üîß Supported Formats

### Text Format (Shell-style)
```
> This is a user message
that can span multiple lines
until there's an empty line

Agent response follows here
with tool calls and system messages

> Another user message
```

**Parsing rules**:
- User messages start with `>`
- Multi-line messages continue until empty line
- Everything else is treated as agent/system response

### JSON Format (Q-Developer)
```json
{
  "messages": [
    {
      "content": {
        "Prompt": "User message content"
      },
      "timestamp": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
    }
  ]
}
```

**Parsing rules**:
- Messages with `content.Prompt` are user messages
- Other messages are agent responses
- Timestamps and metadata preserved

## üé® Themes

| Theme | Description | Colors |
|-------|-------------|---------|
| **Matrix** | Classic green-on-black terminal | `#00ff00` on `#000000` |
| **Amber** | Retro amber monochrome | `#ffb000` on `#1a0f00` |
| **Blue** | Cool blue terminal | `#00aaff` on `#001122` |
| **Hacker** | High-contrast green | `#00ff41` on `#0d1117` |
| **Light** | Modern light theme | `#24292e` on `#ffffff` |

## üõ†Ô∏è Extending the Application

### Adding New Source Adapters

Create a new adapter implementing the `SourceAdapter` interface:

```typescript
// src/adapters/CustomSourceAdapter.ts
import type { SourceAdapter } from '../types'

export class CustomSourceAdapter implements SourceAdapter {
  async fetchContent(url: string): Promise<string> {
    // Implement your source loading logic
    const response = await fetch(url)
    return response.text()
  }
}
```

Register in `SourceInput.vue`:
```typescript
import { CustomSourceAdapter } from '../adapters/CustomSourceAdapter'

// Add to adapter selection logic
const adapter = url.startsWith('custom://') 
  ? new CustomSourceAdapter()
  : new FileSourceAdapter()
```

### Adding New Format Parsers

Create a parser implementing the `FormatParser` interface:

```typescript
// src/parsers/CustomFormatParser.ts
import type { FormatParser, ConversationData } from '../types'

export class CustomFormatParser implements FormatParser {
  async parse(content: string): Promise<ConversationData> {
    // Implement your parsing logic
    return {
      metadata: {
        title: 'Custom Format',
        timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
        format: 'custom'
      },
      messages: [] // Parse your format here
    }
  }
}
```

### Adding New Themes

Add theme definitions to `style.css`:

```css
[data-theme="mytheme"] {
  --terminal-bg: #your-bg-color;
  --terminal-text: #your-text-color;
  --terminal-cursor: #your-cursor-color;
  --terminal-prompt: #your-prompt-color;
}
```

Update the theme type in `types/index.ts`:
```typescript
theme: 'matrix' | 'amber' | 'blue' | 'hacker' | 'light' | 'mytheme'
```

## üß™ Development

### Available Scripts

```bash
# Development server with hot reload
npm run dev

# Type checking
npm run build

# Preview production build
npm run preview
```

### Code Style

The project follows these principles:
- **Readability over brevity**: Verbose, clear code preferred
- **Simple solutions**: Avoid unnecessary complexity
- **Structured development**: Requirements ‚Üí Documentation ‚Üí Tests ‚Üí Implementation
- **TypeScript**: Full type safety throughout

### Component Architecture

- **Composition API**: Vue 3 `<script setup>` syntax
- **Scoped styling**: Component-specific CSS with global theme system
- **Props/Events**: Clear component interfaces
- **Reactive state**: Vue's reactivity system for UI updates

## üéØ Use Cases

- **Development teams**: Review and analyze LLM conversations
- **AI researchers**: Study conversation patterns and flows
- **Documentation**: Create interactive conversation examples
- **Training**: Demonstrate LLM interaction patterns
- **Debugging**: Replay conversations to identify issues

## ü§ù Contributing

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch: `git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`
3. Follow the coding guidelines in the project
4. Add tests for new functionality
5. Commit changes: `git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`
6. Push to branch: `git push origin feature/amazing-feature`
7. Open a Pull Request

## üìÑ License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.

## üôè Acknowledgments

- Built with Vue 3, TypeScript, and Vite
- Icons from Lucide Vue Next
- Terminal aesthetics inspired by classic command-line interfaces
- Typewriter animations for authentic conversation replay experience
args.old_str:
# Vue 3 + TypeScript + Vite

This template should help get you started developing with Vue 3 and TypeScript in Vite. The template uses Vue 3 `<script setup>` SFCs, check out the [script setup docs](https://v3.vuejs.org/api/sfc-script-setup.html#sfc-script-setup) to learn more.

Learn more about the recommended Project Setup and IDE Support in the [Vue Docs TypeScript Guide](https://vuejs.org/guide/typescript/overview.html#project-setup).

orig_args.old_str:
# Vue 3 + TypeScript + Vite

This template should help get you started developing with Vue 3 and TypeScript in Vite. The template uses Vue 3 `<script setup>` SFCs, check out the [script setup docs](https://v3.vuejs.org/api/sfc-script-setup.html#sfc-script-setup) to learn more.

Learn more about the recommended Project Setup and IDE Support in the [Vue Docs TypeScript Guide](https://vuejs.org/guide/typescript/overview.html#project-setup).

Response.content:
I've created a comprehensive README that covers all aspects of your LLM conversation replay application. The README includes:

## Key Sections Added:

1. **Project Overview** - Clear description with feature badges
2. **Feature Highlights** - Organized into logical categories (Interactive Playback, Terminal Interface, Architecture, Customization)
3. **Quick Start Guide** - Installation and basic usage instructions
4. **Project Structure** - Complete file organization with descriptions
5. **Format Documentation** - Detailed explanation of both supported formats (shell-style text and Q-Developer JSON)
6. **Theme Gallery** - Visual reference for all available themes
7. **Extension Guide** - Step-by-step instructions for adding new adapters, parsers, and themes
8. **Development Guidelines** - Scripts, code style, and architecture principles
9. **Use Cases** - Real-world applications for the tool
10. **Contributing Guidelines** - Standard open-source contribution workflow

## Notable Features:

- **Visual elements**: Badges, tables, and code blocks for better readability
- **Practical examples**: Real code snippets for extending the application
- **Clear structure**: Logical flow from overview to detailed implementation
- **Developer-focused**: Emphasizes the extensible architecture and customization options
- **Complete coverage**: Documents all major components and features

The README follows modern documentation standards with emoji icons for visual appeal and comprehensive technical details that would help both users and contributors understand and extend the application effectively.

Response.content:
The changes I made:

1. **Made the terminal-container absolutely positioned** - This removes it from the normal document flow so it's not affected by the main-container's flex layout
2. **Set it to cover the entire conversation-area** - Using `top: 0, left: 0, right: 0, bottom: 0`
3. **Used flexbox centering within the absolute container** - This properly centers the terminal both horizontally and vertically
4. **Added 5vh/5vw padding** - This ensures the terminal (90% size) is perfectly centered with equal margins on all sides

Now the terminal should be perfectly centered on the screen, taking exactly 90% of both width and height, with equal margins on all sides regardless of the main container's layout.

Prompt.prompt: now, the settings are not visible. Move them in a simple dialog (no own component)

ToolUse.content: I'll move the settings into a simple dialog overlay instead of a sidebar panel. This will ensure the settings are always visible when toggled, regardless of the terminal layout.

args.new_str: Settings

orig_args.new_str: Settings

ToolUse.content: Now I'll add the dialog styles:

args.new_str:
<style scoped>
.icon {
  width: 16px;
  height: 16px;
}

.conversation-area {
  position: relative;
}

.terminal-container {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  padding: 5vh 5vw;
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

.terminal-container :deep(.terminal-window) {
  width: 90vw;
  height: 90vh;
  max-width: 90vw;
  max-height: 90vh;
  min-width: 90vw;
  min-height: 90vh;
}

/* Settings Dialog */
.settings-dialog-overlay {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.7);
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  z-index: 1000;
  backdrop-filter: blur(4px);
}

.settings-dialog {
  background-color: var(--color-bg-primary);
  border: 1px solid var(--color-border);
  border-radius: 12px;
  width: 90%;
  max-width: 500px;
  max-height: 80vh;
  overflow: hidden;
  box-shadow: 0 20px 40px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
}

.settings-header {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  align-items: center;
  padding: var(--spacing-3);
  border-bottom: 1px solid var(--color-border);
  background-color: var(--color-bg-secondary);
}

.settings-header h3 {
  margin: 0;
  color: var(--color-text-primary);
  font-size: var(--font-size-lg);
}

.close-btn {
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 24px;
  color: var(--color-text-secondary);
  cursor: pointer;
  padding: 4px 8px;
  border-radius: 4px;
  transition: var(--transition);
}

.close-btn:hover {
  background-color: var(--color-bg-tertiary);
  color: var(--color-text-primary);
}

.settings-content {
  padding: var(--spacing-3);
  max-height: calc(80vh - 80px);
  overflow-y: auto;
}
</style>

Response.content:
Perfect! I've moved the settings from a sidebar panel to a modal dialog. Here's what I changed:

## Changes Made:

1. **Removed the sidebar layout** - No more `aside` element that was taking up space
2. **Added a modal dialog overlay** - Fixed positioned overlay that covers the entire screen
3. **Created a centered dialog box** - Contains the settings panel with proper styling
4. **Added backdrop blur effect** - Modern glass-morphism effect for better visual separation
5. **Added close functionality** - Click outside the dialog or the √ó button to close
6. **Responsive sizing** - Dialog takes 90% width up to 500px max, with 80% max height

## Key Features:

- **Always visible when toggled** - No layout conflicts with the terminal
- **Proper z-index** - Appears above everything else (z-index: 1000)
- **Click-to-close** - Click overlay background or √ó button to close
- **Scrollable content** - If settings get too long, they scroll within the dialog
- **Consistent theming** - Uses the same CSS variables as the rest of the app

Now the settings dialog will appear as a centered modal overlay that doesn't interfere with the terminal's fixed positioning, and users can easily access and close it.

transcript:
> this repo contains a simple app which I created with a single prompt:> 
> 
REQUIREMENTS:> 
> 
Input:> 
> 
Accept conversation source URL (file/gist) via query parameter> 
Support multiple source types through adapter pattern> 
Support multiple conversation formats through parser adapters> 
Core Features:> 
> 
Parse and identify:> 
Human messages> 
Agent responses> 
Tool calls/system messages (including failures)> 
Interactive playback:> 
Typewriter text animation> 
Enter key to progress> 
Tab key to complete current message> 
Ghost preview of upcoming user messages> 
Configurable animation speeds> 
Progress indicators> 
UI/UX:> 
> 
Terminal-style interface with:> 
Monospace font> 
Cursor animations> 
Command prompt styling> 
Message type indicators> 
Settings panel:> 
Animation speed controls (separate for human/agent)> 
Terminal theme options> 
Visual preferences> 
System-aware dark mode> 
Minimal, developer-focused aesthetic> 
Clear interaction instructions> 
Technical Implementation:> 
> 
Vue 3 Composition API> 
Vite build system> 
CSS Architecture:> 
Global stylesheet for common elements> 
Scoped component styles> 
CSS custom properties for theming> 
Component Structure:> 
Source adapters (FileAdapter, GistAdapter)> 
Parser adapters (format-specific)> 
Terminal component> 
Settings panel> 
Message renderer> 
Animation controller> 
Clean Architecture:> 
Separate concerns (parsing, rendering, playback)> 
State management> 
Event handling> 
Configuration management> 
Deliverables:> 
> 
Modular, maintainable codebase> 
Responsive, accessible interface> 
Extensible adapter system> 
Documentation for adding new sources/formats> 
Attached, you find two sample formats:> 
> 
a text format, copied from the shell. User messages are identifyable with the > and may be multi-line. Consider all lines that follow until there's an empty line as one prompt.> 
a json format, exported from q-developer. There, all user prompts can be identified by content.Prompt> 
---> 
> 
the LLM responded with > 
> 
---> 
Based on your requirements, I'll create a comprehensive Vue.js application for replaying LLM conversations with a terminal-style interface and interactive playback features. We'll focus on a clean, developer-focused aesthetic with extensible adapter architecture.> 
> 
Core Features:> 
> 
Source and parser adapter pattern for multiple conversation formats> 
Interactive playback with typewriter animations and keyboard controls> 
Terminal-style interface with cursor animations and command prompt styling> 
Settings panel for animation speeds and visual preferences> 
Real-time progress indicators and ghost preview system> 
Design Elements:> 
> 
Monospace typography with terminal aesthetics and proper contrast ratios> 
System-aware dark mode with comprehensive color system (6+ color ramps)> 
Responsive design with mobile (<768px), tablet (768-1024px), and desktop (>1024px) breakpoints> 
8px spacing system with intentional white space and visual hierarchy> 
Subtle animations and micro-interactions for enhanced user engagement> 
LLM Conversation Replay Vue.js Application> 
> 
Revert> 
> 
package.json> 
npm install> 
src/App.vue> 
src/components/SourceInput.vue> 
src/components/SettingsPanel.vue> 
src/components/ConversationTerminal.vue> 
src/components/MessageRenderer.vue> 
src/components/TypewriterText.vue> 
src/components/ProgressIndicator.vue> 
src/types/index.ts> 
src/adapters/FileSourceAdapter.ts> 
src/adapters/GistSourceAdapter.ts> 
src/parsers/TextFormatParser.ts> 
src/parsers/JsonFormatParser.ts> 
src/style.css> 
npm run dev> 
I've created a comprehensive Vue.js application for replaying LLM conversations with all the features you requested. The application includes:> 
> 
Architecture & Features Implemented:> 
> 
Source Adapters: FileSourceAdapter and GistSourceAdapter for different content sources> 
Parser Adapters: TextFormatParser for shell-style format and JsonFormatParser for Q-Developer format> 
Interactive Playback: Typewriter animations, Enter/Tab/Esc controls, and auto-play functionality> 
Terminal Interface: Monospace fonts, cursor animations, command prompt styling with message type indicators> 
Settings Panel: Animation speed controls, theme selection, and visual preference toggles> 
Design & UX:> 
> 
System-aware dark mode with 4 terminal themes (Matrix, Amber, Blue, Hacker)> 
Responsive design with proper breakpoints for mobile, tablet, and desktop> 
8px spacing system with consistent typography and visual hierarchy> 
Micro-interactions including hover states, transitions, and progress indicators> 
Accessible contrast ratios and readable typography throughout> 
Technical Implementation:> 
> 
Vue 3 Composition API with TypeScript for type safety> 
Clean component architecture with separation of concerns> 
Extensible adapter pattern for easy addition of new sources and formats> 
Local storage for user preferences and settings persistence> 
URL parameter support for direct source loading> 
The application can parse both your sample formats - the shell-style text format (with > for user messages) and the Q-Developer JSON format. The demo button provides an immediate example of how conversations replay with typewriter effects.> 
> 
To extend the application with new formats or sources, simply create new adapter classes implementing the respective interfaces. The modular design makes it easy to add features like audio playback, export functionality, or additional conversation sources.> 
---> 
> 
Create a comprehensive readme that your colleague missd out on

I'll create a comprehensive README for your LLM conversation replay application. Let me first examine the current project structure to understand what's already implemented.

> t

I've created a comprehensive README that covers all aspects of your LLM conversation replay application. The README includes:

## Key Sections Added:

1. **Project Overview** - Clear description with feature badges

ToolSpecification.name: use_aws
ToolSpecification.description: Make an AWS CLI api call with the specified service, operation, and parameters. All arguments MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. Should the output of the invocation indicate a malformed command, invoke help to obtain the the correct command.

service_name.description: The name of the AWS service. If you want to query s3, you should use s3api if possible.

region.description: Region name for calling the operation on AWS.

operation_name.description: The name of the operation to perform.

parameters.description: The parameters for the operation. The parameter keys MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. You should prefer to use JSON Syntax over shorthand syntax wherever possible. For parameters that are booleans, prioritize using flags with no value. Denote these flags with flag names as key and an empty string as their value. You should also prefer kebab case.

label.description: Human readable description of the api that is being called.

profile_name.description: Optional: AWS profile name to use from ~/.aws/credentials. Defaults to default profile if not specified.

ToolSpecification.name: report_issue
ToolSpecification.description: Opens the browser to a pre-filled gh (GitHub) issue template to report chat issues, bugs, or feature requests. Pre-filled information includes the conversation transcript, chat context, and chat request IDs from the service.

expected_behavior.description: Optional: The expected chat behavior or action that did not happen.

steps_to_reproduce.description: Optional: Previous user chat requests or steps that were taken that may have resulted in the issue or error response.

title.description: The title of the GitHub issue.

actual_behavior.description: Optional: The actual chat behavior that happened and demonstrates the issue or lack of a feature.

ToolSpecification.name: dummy
ToolSpecification.description: This is a dummy tool. If you are seeing this that means the tool associated with this tool call is not in the list of available tools. This could be because a wrong tool name was supplied or the list of tools has changed since the conversation has started. Do not show this when user asks you to list tools.

ToolSpecification.name: fs_write
ToolSpecification.description:
A tool for creating and editing files
 * The `create` command will override the file at `path` if it already exists as a file, and otherwise create a new file
 * The `append` command will add content to the end of an existing file, automatically adding a newline if the file doesn't end with one. The file must exist.
 Notes for using the `str_replace` command:
 * The `old_str` parameter should match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the original file. Be mindful of whitespaces!
 * If the `old_str` parameter is not unique in the file, the replacement will not be performed. Make sure to include enough context in `old_str` to make it unique
 * The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that should replace the `old_str`.

new_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string. Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert. Required parameter of `append` command containing the content to append to the file.

command.description: The commands to run. Allowed options are: `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `append`.

path.description: Absolute path to file or directory, e.g. `/repo/file.py` or `/repo`.

file_text.description: Required parameter of `create` command, with the content of the file to be created.

old_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace.

insert_line.description: Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.

summary.description: A brief explanation of what the command does

ToolSpecification.name: fs_read
ToolSpecification.description:
Tool for reading files (for example, `cat -n`),  directories (for example, `ls -la`) and images. If user has supplied paths that appear to be leading to images, you should use this tool right away using Image mode. The behavior of this tool is determined by the `mode` parameter. The available modes are:
- line: Show lines in a file, given by an optional `start_line` and optional `end_line`.
- directory: List directory contents. Content is returned in the "long format" of ls (that is, `ls -la`).
- search: Search for a pattern in a file. The pattern is a string. The matching is case insensitive.

Example Usage:
1. Read all lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt"
2. Read the last 5 lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt", start_line=-5
3. List the files in the home directory: command="line", path="~"
4. Recursively list files in a directory to a max depth of 2: command="line", path="/path/to/directory", depth=2
5. Search for all instances of "test" in a file: command="search", path="/path/to/file.txt", pattern="test"

path.description: Path to the file or directory. The path should be absolute, or otherwise start with ~ for the user's home.

pattern.description: Pattern to search for (required, for Search mode). Case insensitive. The pattern matching is performed per line.

start_line.description: Starting line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

mode.description: The mode to run in: `Line`, `Directory`, `Search`. `Line` and `Search` are only for text files, and `Directory` is only for directories. `Image` is for image files, in this mode `image_paths` is required.

context_lines.description: Number of context lines around search results (optional, for Search mode)

end_line.description: Ending line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

depth.description: Depth of a recursive directory listing (optional, for Directory mode)

image_paths.description: List of paths to the images. This is currently supported by the Image mode.
